text: Exactly. This isn‚Äôt ideological. People respond to incentives. When taxes keep rising, crime worsens, and regulation tightens, capital and talent leave. What the UK loses doesn‚Äôt disappear it becomes another country's gain.

text:
Ernmm, they're not. The so called "study" the think tanks, who continue to perpetuate the lie that the rich are leaving the UK, keep citing, is discovered to have been  based on a comment on "something we saw on LinkedIn" üòÇ come on, let's have some honesty. Then again, what else can we expect for pricks like the staff at the Institute for Economic Affairs and their kind? Look at who pays them to say the crap they say. 

I'm with Gary Stevenson, time to tax wealth, not work. Bring in a wealth tax on the super rich on the wealth they earn on assets in the UK... These people are NOT mobile, they can't leave because assets are fixed.

text: The vast majority of "millionaires" who exit are simply people who have sold their house and everything they own and have a few savings. These people have always been attracted by somewhere sunny - retirement to Spain, Cyprus, Malta, etc. The trouble is, it is too easy to be a millionaire. Millionaires exiting as a metric is quite deceptive. The "truly rich" have already lived in some tax haven for years.

text:

Britain needs to lower it's taxes and regulations - as simple as that! And watch the economy flourish, including the lower income groups.
